title: 104_s850
content: The "Child Care and Development Block Grant Amendments Act of 1995" authorizes appropriations for the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "Child Care and Development Block Grant Amendments Act of 1995" authorizes appropriations of $1,000,000,000 for fiscal year 1996 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1997 through 2000. Amendments are made to the lead agency and application and plan sections of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to implement changes over a 2-year period. Subsection (c) is also modified to ensure appropriate payment mechanisms are in place. The Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to implement changes over a 2-year period, including ensuring proper payment mechanisms for providers within the State. Additionally, the Secretary will develop minimum child care standards in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations. The Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to implement changes over a 2-year period, including developing minimum child care standards in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations. This includes adjustments to the percentage of assistance provided to tribal organizations. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to limit administrative costs to 5% of payments received by a State each fiscal year. Additionally, a sliding fee scale provision is added to the Act. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to ensure a representative distribution of funding among the working poor and recipients of Federal welfare assistance. Eligibility requirements are changed to 100 percent, and quality standards are updated to remove the minimum percentage requirement for certain activities. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to ensure fair funding distribution among low-income families. Eligibility requirements are updated to 100 percent, and quality standards are improved by expanding activities and services offered. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include additional activities such as before- and after-school care, infant care, and child care during nontraditional work hours. Nondiscrimination is emphasized for child care providers complying with state laws but not required to be licensed. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include additional activities such as before- and after-school care, infant care, and child care during nontraditional work hours. Nondiscrimination is emphasized for child care providers participating in resource and referral activities. Section 658H is repealed, and enforcement measures are amended to include reimbursement for improperly expended funds. Section 658K is amended to adjust reporting requirements and enforcement measures for improperly expended funds. Section 658K is amended to adjust reporting requirements and enforcement measures for improperly expended funds. Amendments include changes to subparagraphs, redesignation of paragraphs, and adjustments to paragraph content. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include new reporting requirements and adjustments to resource and referral activities carried out by the State. Amendments also involve changes to reporting timelines, agency names, and allotments for construction or renovation of facilities. An Indian tribe or tribal organization can request funds for construction or renovation of facilities for child care programs if the Secretary determines that adequate facilities are not available, hindering program operation in the future. The Secretary may allow an Indian tribe or organization to use funds for construction or renovation of facilities for child care programs to prevent hindrance in program operation in the future. However, this is subject to the condition that the level of child care services provided should not decrease compared to the previous fiscal year. The Secretary shall develop uniform procedures for soliciting and considering requests under this paragraph. Any portion of a grant or contract to an Indian tribe that is not used consistently with program provisions may be subject to review. The Secretary will reallocate unused grant or contract funds to other tribes or organizations in proportion to their original allocations. Definitions in the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act are amended to include deposits for child care services and additional family members in care provider residences. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section regarding the application of the subchapter. This amendment removes certain language and clarifies the registration process. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to ensure that states using federal funding for child care services comply with the requirements of the subchapter. Funding must be integrated into the state's program established under this subchapter. Additionally, a sense of the Senate is included in the legislation. The Senate emphasizes the importance of quality, affordable, and accessible child care for parents transitioning from welfare to work or education. It is crucial for job training, entering the workforce, and maintaining employment. Lack of quality child care is a significant barrier to employment and self-sufficiency. The Senate emphasizes the importance of federal funding and leadership for child care, highlighting the responsibility of the government in ensuring accessibility and quality care for parents transitioning to work or education. SEC. 4. REPEALS AND TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The State Dependent Care Development Grants Act and the Child Development Associate Scholarship Assistance Act of 1985 are repealed. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a legislative proposal for technical and conforming amendments within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit the implementing bill as referenced in paragraph (1).
